ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: The course covered a wide range of material, and its arrangement helped me track developments and innovations in the genre. I was especially grateful for the amount of Spanish-language drama in the course, which is a body of work that is not as well represented in other parts of the curriculum.

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: There were sessions in which discussion was lively and focused, and there were sessions in which discussion really stalled. It felt like discussion picked up as the year went on, so perhaps some of the lagging discussion can be attributed to affinity for or familiarity with the material.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: I felt the amount of assigned reading was just the right amount, especially given that many of the plays are so rich, having only one play, such as "Heartbreak House," gave us time to explore its many dimensions.

There were not a lot of supplementary media files, which I did not feel was a deficiency in this course. The syllabus B material, which are critical works, are great, but I never took the initiative to read them (I was auditing the course, so perhaps if I was taking the course for credit, this would have been different).
Jim has proven over and over again to have an impeccable library of material at his disposal. Outstanding!

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: This course gave me a familiarity with a genre that I think still has great impact in the field. I would not have read many of these works outside of this course. In fact, without Jim Leverett, I'm not sure I would have read Shaw at the Drama School at all!

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: Yes, I would recommend it to students in dramaturgy. I'm not sure I would recommend it to students in other departments.

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: As mentioned previously, the course did seem to stall at times. I'm not sure if this was because the group was somewhat inattentive or that as a group we weren't the best at reading the assignments. On another note, I think that putting some of the critical writings on the A Syllabus might actually help the discussion. Sometimes I thought the discussion could be kicked into gear if we had something to read alongside the play, such as an essay, letter, etc.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: Jim is a fantastic instructor and his courses have been a major part of my development as a dramaturg at the Drama School.

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: All of them.
All.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: It was MUCH closer to 75% than 50%, but my participation was somewhat lackluster in the course.

My only question left toward the end of the class was the following: how can we differentiate (and should we) between farces and tragicomedies? It is much easier to spot a tragedy and a comedy with a happy ending; however, farces already have the darkness/macabre/grotesque of the tragicomic in it. Should we dismiss the slippage? Or maybe the genres are not mutually exclusive?
